questions.question:
Question 1: A biker met with an accident and sustained a maxillofacial injury. Which of the following is 
the first step in the primary care of this patient?
questions.explanation:
The first step in primary care of a patient with a maxillofacial injury is securing an adequate 
airway. Evaluation of facial fractures: • A & B – Airway & Breathing: the first objective is to ensure an adequate airway by 
intubation or tracheostomy. • C – Circulation: control of haemorrhage by pressure or ligation of bleeding vessels. • Rule out head and spinal injuries. • Neurological evaluation. • Examine for injuries in other parts of the body. • Care of the wound. • Documentation of the injuries for medico-legal purposes. • Examination of the facial skeleton – mandible, maxilla, zygomatic and orbital fracture.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following facial bones is most commonly fractured?
questions.explanation:
The most commonly fractured bone of the face is the nasal bone because of the projection of the 
nose on the face.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 30-year-old man presented with a nasal bleed after sustaining a blow to the nose in a 
fistfight. On evaluation, a nasal septal fracture similar to the one in the image below was 
identified. What is your diagnosis? 384 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of nasal bleed following trauma and the image showing a horizontal 
fracture line is suggestive of Jarjaway fracture. It is a fracture of the nasal septum that results from direct blows from the front. The fracture line 
runs horizontally from just above the anterior nasal spine to just above the junction of septal 
cartilage with vomer. Option C: Chevallet fracture results from blows from below. The fracture line runs vertically from 
the anterior nasal spine upwards to the junction of the bony and cartilaginous dorsum of the nose. 392 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: Tripod fracture is another name for zygoma fracture.

questions.question:
Question 4: A young adult presents with a deformed nose after falling from a ladder. The CT scan shows a 
displaced nasal fracture. What is the ideal time to reduce the fracture in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The ideal time for reduction of fracture of the nasal bone is 5-7 days following injury, once the 
edema has subsided. The presence of edema interferes with the accurate reduction of the fracture. In most cases, the 
deformity is due to edema. So, ice packs and head elevation are advised initially after injury. After 
3-5 days, the edema would subside and the underlying deformity will be apparent on clinical 
assessment. After 2 weeks it is difficult to reduce since the process of callus formation and the bony and 
fibrous union would have started.

questions.question:
Question 5: As an ENT resident, you are assisting in the reduction of a nasal bone fracture. Which of the 
following instruments would you use? 385 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Walsham forceps (Image 2) is used to reduce a nasal bone fracture. Asch forceps is mainly used to reduce nasal septum fracture. 393 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: Luc’s forceps is used in Caldwell Luc operation, submucous resection, and polypectomy. 394 
Sold by @itachibot Option C: Tilley’s forceps is used in nasal packing in the epistaxis. Option D: Citelli’s forceps is used for bone punch. 395

questions.question:
Question 6: A boxer is wheeled into the ER with complaints of seeing double after having suffered a 
severe blow to his face during a match. On examination, there is a flattening of malar 
prominence, trismus and a step deformity of the infraorbital margin. What is the likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of diplopia, flat malar prominence, trismus, and step deformity in the 
infraorbital margin is suggestive of fracture of zygoma or tripod fracture. Zygoma is the second most frequently fractured bone in the face. The zygoma fracture is separated 
at its three processes - the zygomaticofrontal suture, infraorbital margin, and the 
zygomaticotemporal suture. It has the following clinical features: • Flattening of malar prominence. • Trismus, due to depression of zygoma on the underlying coronoid process. • Anesthesia in the distribution of the infraorbital nerve. • Step deformity of infraorbital margin. • Oblique palpebral fissure, due to the displacement of lateral palpebral ligament. • Restricted ocular movements, due to entrapment of inferior rectus muscle. It may cause 
diplopia. • Periorbital emphysema, due to escape of air from the maxillary sinus on nose blowing. The following x-ray shows a right-sided zygoma fracture: 396 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: You are an ENT resident evaluating a patient with a fracture of the zygoma. Which of the 
following findings would you not expect to see in this patient?
questions.explanation:
CSF rhinorrhea is not seen in patients with fractures of the zygoma. It has the following clinical features: • Flattening of malar prominence. • Step deformity of infraorbital margin. • Anesthesia in the distribution of the infraorbital nerve. • Trismus, due to depression of zygoma on the underlying coronoid process. • Oblique palpebral fissure, due to the displacement of lateral palpebral ligament. • Restricted ocular movements, due to entrapment of inferior rectus muscle. It may cause 
diplopia. • Periorbital emphysema, due to escape of air from the maxillary sinus on nose blowing. The following x-ray shows a right-sided zygoma fracture: 397 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: A patient with a tripod fracture is having decreased sensation over the cheek. Which of the 
following nerve injuries can result in this?
questions.explanation:
Infraorbital nerve injury results in decreased sensation over the cheek in tripod(zygomatic) 
fracture.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is called blow-out fractures?

options.b: Fracture of lateral wall of orbit
options.c: Fracture of medial wall of orbit

questions.explanation: Fracture of the floor of the orbit is called blow-out fracture. It occurs when a large blunt object strikes the globe.

questions.question:
Question 10: A teenage boy suffered trauma to his left eye while playing cricket. He is rushed to the ER in 
severe pain. His X-ray appears as below. What is the characteristic sign noted? 387 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given X-ray shows the tear-drop sign. It is seen in orbital floor or blow-out fractures when the 
orbital contents herniate into the maxillary antrum. Option B: Phelp’s sign is seen in CT scan in glomus jugulare tumor. It is the erosion of the normal 
crest of bone between the carotid canal and jugular foramen. Options C and D: Antral and Holman Miller signs are the same. It is the anterior bowing of the 
posterior wall of the maxillary sinus and is pathognomonic of juvenile nasopharyngeal 
angiofibroma. 398 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: A 19-year-old college student presented with complaints of seeing double after sustaining a 
blow to his face in a scuffle with his seniors. On examination, there is a step deformity and 
periorbital emphysema. Entrapment of which of the following muscles is likely to be 
responsible for his double vision?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with diplopia, periorbital emphysema, and a step deformity can be 
seen in both orbital floor fracture as well as tripod fracture. In both conditions diplopia is due to: • Entrapment of inferior rectus and inferior oblique muscles • Displacement of the eyeball. The common features seen in both orbital floor fracture and tripod fracture are: • Periorbital emphysema • Step deformity of infraorbital margin • Diplopia • Enophthalmos.

questions.question: Question 12: In which of the following fractures Le-Fort classification is used?
questions.explanation: Le-Fort classification is used in the fracture of the maxilla. The 3 types are: • Le Fort I (transverse fracture) • Le Fort II (pyramidal fracture) • Le Fort III (craniofacial disjunction).

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following bones is not involved in Le-Fort fractures?
questions.explanation:
399 
Sold by @itachibot The mandible is not involved in Le-Fort’s fractures.

questions.question:
Question 14: The CT scan of a patient who met with a motorcycle accident shows a fracture of the maxilla. 
The fracture line passes through the floor of the nose separating the palate from the rest of 
the face. How will you classify the fracture?
questions.explanation: The CT findings describe a Le-Fort I fracture of the maxilla. It is also known as Guerin’s fracture.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is the most common site for fracture of the mandible in children?
questions.explanation:
The most common site of fracture of the mandible in children is the condyle. It is because the 
condylar head is connected to the vertical ramus of the bone by a thin neck which gives away 
easily to an impact. Mandibular fractures: Children: • Due to falls and sports injuries. • Most common site - condyle. Adults > 50 years: • Most commonly due to falls. • Most common site - body (the molar area is the weakest area in an edentulous mandible). Young Adults: • Due to falls, assaults, and accidents. • The site of fracture depends on the nature of impact and the direction of force applied.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 23-year-old college student presented with jaw pain and trismus after falling from a bike. A 
diagnosis of mandibular fracture was made. Which of the following classification is used for 
this?
questions.explanation:
Dingman’s classification is used in the classification of fractures of the mandible. Dingman's classification is based on the region in which the fracture is located. The seven regions 
used in this classification are as shown below: 400 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: Le-Fort classification is used in maxillary fractures. Option C: Gartland classification is used in supracondylar fractures of the humerus. Option D: Pauwell classification is used in the neck of femur fractures.

questions.question:
Question 17: Following trauma, a patient presented with clear watery nasal discharge that cannot be 
sniffed back. Fractures of which of the following bones is the most likely cause for this?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of CSF rhinorrhea and fracture of the cribriform plate of 
the ethmoid is the most common cause for this. Causes of CSF rhinorrhea: • Trauma (accidental or surgical) - most of the cases follow trauma. Surgical trauma includes 
endoscopic sinus surgery, trans-sphenoidal hypophysectomy, nasal polypectomy, or skull base 
surgery. • Inflammations - mucoceles of sinuses, sinonasal polyposis, the fungal infection of sinuses and 
osteomyelitis, can all erode the bone and dura. • Neoplasms - tumours, both benign and malignant, invading the skull base. • Congenital lesions - meningocele, meningoencephaloceles, and gliomas can have associated skull 
base defects. • Idiopathic - where the cause is unknown and the patient has a spontaneous leak.

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following fractures is not associated with CSF rhinorrhea?
questions.explanation:
Le-Fort I fracture is not associated with CSF rhinorrhea. Whereas, fractures like Le-Fort II, III 
and naso-orbito-ethmoid fracture are associated with CSF rhinorrhea. 401 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 19: A middle-aged woman, who had undergone a polypectomy complains of watery nasal 
discharge on bending forward. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of CSF rhinorrhea secondary to surgery. Identifying features of CSF Rhinorrhea: 1. The CSF discharge is thin, watery, and clear in appearance. 2. It cannot be sniffed back. (Option D) 3. It does not stiffen a handkerchief. 4. It shows positional variation: The watery CSF discharge occurs suddenly and gushes in drops 
only on bending the head forward/straining. 5. The Halo sign is a marker of CSF rhinorrhea post-head trauma. It is considered positive when a 
clear ring surrounds a central bloody spot after the discharge is dropped on a handkerchief/paper 
towel. 6. Reservoir sign: The discharge is seen on rising in the morning and bending the head, as fluid 
accumulated in the sinuses empties into the nose.

questions.question:
Question 20: In a patient with suspected CSF rhinorrhea, the presence of which of the following in the 
nasal discharge will confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Presence of  2 transferrin protein in the nasal discharge confirms the presence of CSF in the 
specimen.  2 transferrin protein detection by electrophoresis is a sensitive and specific test for CSF. It is 
secreted by meninges and choroid plexus. Since it is absent in nasal secretions it helps to differentiate CSF from nasal secretions. It is also 
present in aqueous humor and perilymph. Another method is glucose testing by oxidase peroxidase or biochemical estimation. CSF glucose 
is 60% of blood glucose whereas it is <10mg/dl in nasal secretions. It is not reliable in 
associated meningitis (reduced levels giving false-negative results) and when CSF is mixed with 
blood.

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following is false about CSF rhinorrhea?

options.a: Ethmoid is the most common site of leak
options.c: Intrathecal fluorescein study can be used to detect site of leak

questions.explanation:
Double ring sign is present in a case of CSF rhinorrhea. Double ring sign or Halo sign or Target sign - when CSF mixed with blood is collected on a piece 
of filter paper, it will show a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo. Option A: Fracture cribriform plate of ethmoid is the most common cause. Option B: CSF glucose is 60% of blood glucose. Option C: Intrathecal fluorescein study is used to detect the site of leak of CSF. 402 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 22: What is the preferred line of management in a patient with CSF rhinorrhea who is otherwise 
stable?
questions.explanation:
Patients with CSF rhinorrhea who are stable, are managed conservatively. The conservative measures are: • Bed rest • Elevation of the head end • Stool softeners • Avoidance of nose-blowing, sneezing, and straining. Prophylactic antibiotics can be used to prevent meningitis and acetazolamide to decrease CSF 
formation. Surgery is done if the conservative management fails. 403 
Sold by @itachibot Tumors of Nose and PNS
